statement:
If $R$ is an integral domain with field of fractions $k$ and
$S\subseteq R\setminus\{0\}$ is a multiplicative set, then the
localization at $S$ is given by
$$S^{-1}R=\left\{s^{-1}x:x\in R,s\in S\right\}$$ (up to isomorphism).
This is a subring of $k$, and the following theorem states that
localizations of Dedekind domains are again Dedekind domains.

Let $R$ be a Dedekind domain and $S\subseteq R\setminus\{0\}$ be a
multiplicative set. Then $S^{-1}R$ is a Dedekind domain.

A special case of this is the localization at a prime ideal
$\mathfrak{p}$, which is defined as
$R_\mathfrak{p}\equiv (R\setminus\mathfrak{p})^{-1}R$, and is therefore
a Dedekind domain. In fact, if $\mathfrak{p}$ is nonzero then it can be
shown that $R_\mathfrak{p}$ is a discrete valuation ring.
names: localizations of Dedekind domains are Dedekind
